story_text:
OK so this is a true story. I know how it sounds but I need to get this out there. It was summer 2007 and I was at my Uncle Rick's house because my mom made me "go outside" but also wouldn't let me go to my friend Tyler's. Uncle Rick used to work at a game company (not saying which one for legal reasons) and his garage was full of old stuff from back then. I was going through a box of cables and I found a cartridge. It was all black with no label, just the word "MARIO" scratched into the plastic with something sharp.
I shouldn't have played it. I know that now. But I was eleven and bored and Uncle Rick was asleep in his recliner, so I grabbed his old NES, blew into the cartridge, and plugged it in.
The title screen looked almost normal. It said "SUPER MARIO 128" in red letters, but they were dripping. The background was just black instead of the usual blue sky. Mario was on the title screen like always but he wasn't moving. He was just standing there staring. His eyes were photorealistic. The rest of him was regular pixel Mario but his eyes looked real. The music was the normal theme but slowed down and reversed and every few seconds there was a sound like breathing.

I pressed Start. World 1-1 loaded but the ground was red and the sky was black. There were no enemies. No coins. Just Mario running right in total silence. I played for maybe ten minutes, just going through empty levels that kept getting more wrong. Pipes that led nowhere. Blocks that bled when you hit them. A flagpole at the end of 1-4 with something hanging from it that I'm not going to describe.
Then I fell asleep. I don't remember closing my eyes. One second I was sitting on Uncle Rick's carpet and the next I was standing on red ground under a black sky and my shoes were made of pixels.

I started screaming. I don't even know why. Something about those eyes just made me completely lose it. Uncle Rick woke up so fast he knocked his beer over and he was in the doorway going "what? WHAT?" and I was just pointing at the TV crying.
He looked at the screen and got really quiet. I had never seen Uncle Rick look like that. He walked over and pulled the cartridge out without even turning the NES off. He didn't look at me. He just said "where did you find this" and I pointed at the box. He put the cartridge in his pocket and told me to go inside and watch TV.
I heard him go out to the driveway and when I looked through the window he was on his phone pacing around. He kept rubbing his head the way he does when he's upset. He drove me home early that day and when I asked about the cartridge in the car he just turned up the radio.
That night I had a dream about the title screen. The black background and the red letters and Mario just standing there. Except in the dream I was closer to the TV than I had been in real life and I could see that Mario's mouth was moving. Like he was trying to say something. I woke up and my TV was on even though I always turn it off before bed. It was just static.
I tried asking Uncle Rick about it the next time I saw him and he said "I don't know what you're talking about." Not in a lying way. In a way where he genuinely didn't seem to remember. Which doesn't make sense because I SAW his face when he looked at that screen.

choice_text: I woke up the next day and my mom told me that uncle Rick was missing
story_text:
She was doing that thing where she's trying to sound calm but her voice is too high and she's gripping her coffee mug with both hands. She said Grandma had called him all morning and he wasn't picking up, and when she drove over his front door was open but his truck was in the driveway. She said "I'm sure he's fine" three times in like two minutes which is how I knew she didn't think he was fine.
The cops came by that afternoon to ask if we'd seen him. My mom told them about the open door and the truck. I almost said something about the cartridge. I had this feeling in my stomach like I NEEDED to tell someone about it. But my mom was already upset and the officer was already looking at me the way adults look at kids when they think you're about to make things harder, so I just said I saw him two days ago and he seemed normal.
They found his phone in the garage. That's the part that really got to me. It was sitting on top of the box. The same box where I found the cartridge. The screen was still on when they found it, which shouldn't have been possible because Uncle Rick had one of those old Motorola Razrs and the battery died if you looked at it wrong. His last outgoing call was to a number nobody recognized. When the cops called it back it just rang and rang. No voicemail. No recording. Just ringing.

A Chieftain to the Highlands bound,
Cries, ‘Boatman, do not tarry;
And I’ll give thee a silver pound
To row us o’er the ferry.’

‘Now who be ye would cross Lochgyle,
This dark and stormy water?’

choice_text: Tell the Boatman I'm a prince, threaten to kill him if he doesn't row us o'er the ferry
story_text:
The Chieftain drew himself to his full height upon the rain-lashed shore, his hand falling to the dirk at his belt. "I am a prince of Ulva's isle," he thundered above the gale, "and this lady is my wedded wife. Row us across, old man, or by God and all His saints, I'll open thy throat and take the oars myself."
The boatman shrank back against his vessel, his lantern swinging wild arcs of amber light across the black water. But the lady — Loss Ullin's daughter — laid her pale hand upon the Chieftain's arm. "Speak not so, my love," she whispered, though the wind near swallowed her words. "We flee my father's wrath already. Let us not carry murder with us into the storm."
The boatman's eyes darted between them — the fierce young lord with rain streaming through his dark hair, and the trembling maiden wrapped in a sodden plaid. Behind them, far up the glen, came the unmistakable sound of hoofbeats and the baying of hounds. The old man swallowed hard, then gestured toward the boat with a gnarled hand. "Get in, the both of ye," he muttered. "It's no silver I need — 'tis the look in that lady's eyes that moves me. But mark me well, prince or no — Lochgyle keeps its own counsel on nights such as these."

story_text:
The Chieftain laughed — a wild, reckless sound that cut through the howling wind — and clapped the old boatman on the shoulder hard enough to stagger him. "Peace, old mother hen! Ye cluck worse than the wives at market. Row on and save thy warnings for the gulls." He swung himself into the pitching vessel and pulled his lady after him, catching her waist as she stumbled against the gunwale.
No sooner had the boatman set his oars to water, groaning about the swells and muttering prayers to saints whose names were lost to the gale, than the two lovers fell into one another as though Lochgyle were a millpond on a summer's eve. The Chieftain tucked his lady beneath his plaid, and she pressed her brow to his neck, and their feet tangled together on the rain-slicked boards. He whispered something against her hair that made her laugh — a sound so strange and bright upon that black water that the boatman near crossed himself.
"Will ye sit still," the old man hissed through gritted teeth, for the boat rocked treacherously with their shifting weight. A wave broke cold across the bow. Behind them, torchlight bloomed along the shore they'd left — Lord Ullin's riders had reached the water's edge. But the Chieftain only drew his lady closer and pressed his lips to her rain-wet temple, blind and deaf to all the world's gathering fury.

story_text:
"I am a prince of Ulva's isle,
And this — my wife, Lord Ullin's daughter.
Now row us hence, or by my blade
I'll spill thy blood upon this shore."
The lady clutched his arm and prayed,
"My love, speak death no more."
The boatman marked the lady's eye,
The hounds that bayed behind her —
"Get in," he said. "I'll not ask why.
But Lochgyle's no place to find her."

choice_text: The lovers ignore the boatman's warnings
story_text:
The Chieftain laughed and leapt aboard
And pulled his lady after;
He heeded not the boatman's word,
But traded kiss and laughter.
Their feet entwined on rain-slicked boards,
Her brow against his shoulder —
"Sit still!" the boatman cried. "Good lord,
The waves grow ever bolder!"
But torchlight bloomed along the shore,
Lord Ullin's riders massing —
The Chieftain only held her more,
And cared not what was passing.

choice_text: The boatman tries to kill himself and his passengers
story_text:
They'd scarce reached halfway 'cross the deep
When the boatman's oars fell still.
He rose with eyes like one from sleep
Waked to some dreadful will.
"I've ferried souls through thirty years
Of storm and dark and sorrow —
I've naught to show but salt and tears,
And less to face tomorrow."
He brought his heel upon the floor
And stamped with desperate fury;
The old planks groaned, the black waves pour'd
Through seams like judge and jury.
The lady screamed; the Chieftain swore
And seized the madman's collar —
"What devil's taken thee, old cur?"
But still the waters follow'd.
The boatman laughed — a hollow sound —
"We'll all find peace together!"
The loch crept up, the boat sank down,
And worsened still the weather.

story_text:
But hark — from out the mist there came
A voice of nasal grievance,
A wretched wail that put to shame
The storm in sheer achievement.
A figure stood upon a raft
Of planks and bindings wretched,
Pole-punting through the waves, half-daft,
Soaked through and wholly stretched thin.

"You think YOU'VE got it bad?" he shrieked,
His spectacles askew,
"I'm Malcolm Wilkerson! My life has PEAKED
At nothing — NOTHING — do you hear me? — and Reese drew on my pillow AGAIN and my mom made ME clean the toilet even though it was DEWEY who clogged it and I scored a 99 on my practice SAT and everyone said *that's great Malcolm* but NOBODY MEANS IT!"

He drifted closer, sobbing, flailing his pole at the sky. The boatman paused mid-destruction, bewildered. The Chieftain, still knee-deep in rising loch-water, loosened his grip upon the madman's throat and stared. Even the lady ceased her screaming.

"And FURTHERMORE," Malcolm continued, his voice cracking between octaves, "I have NO friends, my father is EMOTIONALLY ABSENT, and this raft was my SCIENCE PROJECT which I will now receive NO CREDIT for because Mrs. Henshaw said practical demonstrations require a CONTROLLED ENVIRONMENT — does THIS look CONTROLLED to you?!" A wave struck him broadside. He did not stop talking.
